lines.text: It's not me that's crying. It's my eyes.
What kind of man is he?
He's a typical city-hunchback type.
If you start to strangle a cat, finish it off.
A farmer may grow a hump, but a hunchback rarely becomes a farmer.
[first lines]
[dialog in French, lines from English subtitles]
Papet! Papet! It's me, Ugolin!

[to Ugolin]
He'll sell it. A pen makes less blisters than a pickaxe.
Now let's talk about other things. I'm going to write to Scratcher.
Who's she?

You don't know her because she left here before you were born. She had the body of an angel. They called her Scratcher because when the boys tried to kiss her she scratched their faces. She used to sharpen her nails especially. But because of this she ended up a spinster and when her parents died she went to work for the priest at Mimet. About 4 or 5 years ago the pope moved him to Crespin and she should still be with him.
So long as she didn't scratch him.
Oh, at her age you don't scratch people, and because she was a friend of Florette she must still visit her. I'm going to write immediately.
And if she's dead?
Not everyone my age is dead.
A farmer may become a hunchback but it's rare for a hunchback to become a farmer.
I suppose you are going to be charitable and buy the farm?
That depends, what do you think it is worth?
Not much, certainly not the life of a man.
I know all about springs. They're like pretty girls - ignore them and they're gone.
Remember, it's much easier to push something downhill than uphill, so push him in the direction where he'll fall.

[to Ugolin]
It's over here. See. The spring was by the fig tree. Don't look back! Old man Camoins dug a trench that went down to the end of the field there. That way, the water just ran downhill. Understand? Look by my foot. See how soggy the ground is? The water's blocked, but it'd be easy to release it. That slob let it all go to waste!
So, you're the heir?
No. We were only distant cousins.
Ah, but you'll get something.
No, it'll all go to his sister, Florette.
Is she still alive?
Why shouldn't she be? She's younger than you! I heard her husband had died, but not her.
Who's this Florette?

[to Ugolin]
Let's say you pass by with a load of cement? You trip, you fall and bang! The cement plugs up the opening!
Is that why you rented this old farm?
I didn't rent it.
Did you buy it?
I didn't buy it either, but it's all mine.
You're not Jean de Florette, are you?
I'm Jean, and my mother was Florette. But my real name is Jean Cadoret.
If you'd been born here, it would be Jean de Florette.
I also own a spring.
What spring? Where?
It's marked on the land register. Come and take a look. Maybe you can help me locate it.

[to Jean]
Daddy! There's no more water.

[to Ugolin]
Galinette! If this heat wave keeps up his corn and the other vegetables will be wiped out.
I'm a hunchback! Have you forgotten that? Do you think that's easy?
Jean...
Isn't there no one, anybody up there? There's nobody up there! I'm a hunchback! Do you think that's easy? There's nobody up there.
So you won't sell?

Of course not! I'll never sell the house where my mother was born, and where I hope to live forever until I die as a rich man! We can get by quite well on four thousand francs! I'll buy a mule, a load of miner's tools, and some dynamite to blast this damn rock! In a year I'll pay off the mortgage, and we'll be set!
Look at these giant thistles! Look at the house!
[last lines]
[dialog in French, lines from English subtitles]
In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, I hereby name you King of Carnations!
